4.7. Non-classical maximal operator
Let the maximal operator M♦ be defined by
(M♦f)(x) = sup_{r>0} \left| \dashint_{B_r(x)} \frac{y-x}{|y-x|} f(y)\,dy \right|, \quad x \in \mathbb{R}^n,
where f is locally integrable in \mathbb{R}^n and the barred integral stands for the mean value. It is obviously dominated by the Hardy-Littlewood maximal operator M. A simple property of M♦ is the sharp pointwise inequality for functions of one variable
|u′(x)|^2 \le \frac{8}{3} (M♦u)(x)\,(M♦u′′)(x),
see [71, formula (12.0.5)].
Clearly, M♦ is dominated by the sharp maximal operator M♯ defined by
(M♯f)(x) = sup_{r>0} \dashint_{B_r(x)} |f(y) - f_{B_r(x)}|\,dy,
where f_{B_r(x)} stands for the mean value of f in the ball B_r(x).
Problem. Does there exist a Banach space B such that one of the operators M♯ or M♦ is bounded in B whereas the other operator is not bounded?
